t: John 1
Prologue
In*p the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
He was with God in the beginning.
All things were created through him, and apart from him not one thing was created that has been created.
In him was life, and that life was the light of men.
That light shines in the darkness, and yet the darkness did not overcome it.
There*p was a man sent from God whose name was John.
He came as a witness to testify about the light, so that all might believe through him.
He was not the light, but he came to testify about the light.
The true light that gives light to everyone was coming into the world.
He*p was in the world, and the world was created through him, and yet the world did not recognize him.
He came to his own, and his own people did not receive him.
But to all who did receive him, he gave them the right to be children of God, to those who believe in his name,
who were born, not of natural descent, or of the will of the flesh, or of the will of man, but of God.
The*p Word became flesh and dwelt among us. We observed his glory, the glory as the one and only Son from the Father, full of grace and truth.
(John testified concerning him and exclaimed, “This was the one of whom I said, ‘The one coming after me ranks ahead of me, because he existed before me.’”)
Indeed, we have all received grace upon grace from his fullness,
for the law was given through Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
No one has ever seen God. The one and only Son, who is himself God and is at the Father’s side— he has revealed him.
John the Baptist’s Testimony
This*p was John’s testimony when the Jews from Jerusalem sent priests and Levites to ask him, “Who are you?”
He*p didn’t deny it but confessed, “I am not the Messiah.”
“What*p then?” they asked him. “Are you Elijah?” “I*p am not,” he said. “Are*p you the Prophet?” “No,”*p he answered.
“Who*p are you, then?” they asked. “We need to give an answer to those who sent us. What can you tell us about yourself?”
He*p said, “I am a voice*i of*i one*i crying*i out*i in*i the*i wilderness:*i Make*i straight*i the*i way*i of*i the*i Lord*i — just as Isaiah the prophet said.”
Now*p they had been sent from the Pharisees.
So they asked him, “Why then do you baptize if you aren’t the Messiah, or Elijah, or the Prophet?”
“I*p baptize with water,” John answered them. “Someone stands among you, but you don’t know him.
He is the one coming after me, whose sandal strap I’m not worthy to untie.”
All this happened in Bethany across the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
The Lamb of God
The*p next day John saw Jesus coming toward him and said, “Look, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!
This is the one I told you about: ‘After me comes a man who ranks ahead of me, because he existed before me.’
I didn’t know him, but I came baptizing with water so that he might be revealed to Israel.”
And John testified, “I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and he rested on him.
I didn’t know him, but he who sent me to baptize with water told me, ‘The one you see the Spirit descending and resting on — he is the one who baptizes with the Holy Spirit.’
I have seen and testified that this is the Son of God.”
The*p next day, John was standing with two of his disciples.
When he saw Jesus passing by, he said, “Look, the Lamb of God!”
The*p two disciples heard him say this and followed Jesus.
When Jesus turned and noticed them following him, he asked them, “What*r are*r you*r looking*r for?”*r They*p said to him, “Rabbi” (which means “Teacher”), “where are you staying?”
“Come*rp and*r you’ll*r see,”*r he replied. So they went and saw where he was staying, and they stayed with him that day. It was about four in the afternoon.
Andrew,*p Simon Peter’s brother, was one of the two who heard John and followed him.
He first found his own brother Simon and told him, “We have found the Messiah” (which is translated “the Christ”),
and he brought Simon to Jesus. When*p Jesus saw him, he said, “You*r are*r Simon,*r son*r of*r John.*r You*r will*r be*r called*r Cephas”*r (which is translated “Peter”).
Philip and Nathanael
The*p next day Jesus decided to leave for Galilee. He found Philip and told him, “Follow*r me.”*r
Now*p Philip was from Bethsaida, the hometown of Andrew and Peter.
Philip found Nathanael and told him, “We have found the one Moses wrote about in the law (and so did the prophets ): Jesus the son of Joseph, from Nazareth.”
“Can*p anything good come out of Nazareth?” Nathanael asked him. “Come*p and see,” Philip answered.
Then*p Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward him and said about him, “Here*r truly*r is*r an*r Israelite*r in*r whom*r there*r is*r no*r deceit.”*r
“How*p do you know me?” Nathanael asked. “Before*rp Philip*r called*r you,*r when*r you*r were*r under*r the*r fig*r tree,*r I*r saw*r you,”*r Jesus answered.
“Rabbi,”*p Nathanael replied, “You are the Son of God; you are the King of Israel!”
Jesus*p responded to him, “Do*r you*r believe*r because*r I*r told*r you*r I*r saw*r you*r under*r the*r fig*r tree?*r You*r will*r see*r greater*r things*r than*r this.”*r
Then he said, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r you*r will*r see*r heaven*r opened*r and*r the*r angels*r of*r God*r ascending*r and*r descending*r on*r the*r Son*r of*r Man.”*r
John 2
The First Sign: Turning Water into Wine
On*p the third day a wedding took place in Cana of Galilee. Jesus’s mother was there,
and Jesus and his disciples were invited to the wedding as well.
When the wine ran out, Jesus’s mother told him, “They don’t have any wine.”
“What*rp has*r this*r concern*r of*r yours*r to*r do*r with*r me,*r woman?”*r Jesus asked. “My*r hour*r has*r not*r yet*r come.”*r
“Do*p whatever he tells you,” his mother told the servants.
Now*p six stone water jars had been set there for Jewish purification. Each contained twenty or thirty gallons.
“Fill*rp the*r jars*r with*r water,”*r Jesus told them. So they filled them to the brim.
Then he said to them, “Now*r draw*r some*r out*r and*r take*r it*r to*r the*r headwaiter.”*r And they did.
When*p the headwaiter tasted the water (after it had become wine), he did not know where it came from — though the servants who had drawn the water knew. He called the groom
and told him, “Everyone sets out the fine wine first, then, after people are drunk, the inferior. But you have kept the fine wine until now.”
Jesus*p did this, the first of his signs, in Cana of Galilee. He revealed his glory, and his disciples believed in him.
After*p this, he went down to Capernaum, together with his mother, his brothers, and his disciples, and they stayed there only a few days.
Cleansing the Temple
The*p Jewish Passover was near, and so Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
In the temple he found people selling oxen, sheep, and doves, and he also found the money changers sitting there.
After making a whip out of cords, he drove everyone out of the temple with their sheep and oxen. He also poured out the money changers’ coins and overturned the tables.
He told those who were selling doves, “Get*r these*r things*r out*r of*r here!*r Stop*r turning*r my*r Father’s*r house*r into*r a*r marketplace!”*r
And*p his disciples remembered that it is written: Zeal*i for*i your*i house*i will*i consume*i me.*i
So*p the Jews replied to him, “What sign will you show us for doing these things?”
Jesus*p answered, “Destroy*r this*r temple,*r and*r I*r will*r raise*r it*r up*r in*r three*r days.”*r
Therefore*p the Jews said, “This temple took forty-six years to build, and will you raise it up in three days?”
But*p he was speaking about the temple of his body.
So when he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this, and they believed the Scripture and the statement Jesus had made.
While*p he was in Jerusalem during the Passover Festival, many believed in his name when they saw the signs he was doing.
Jesus, however, would not entrust himself to them, since he knew them all
and because he did not need anyone to testify about man; for he himself knew what was in man.
John 3
Jesus and Nicodemus
There*p was a man from the Pharisees named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.
This man came to him at night and said, “Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher who has come from God, for no one could perform these signs you do unless God were with him.”
Jesus*p replied, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r unless*r someone*r is*r born*r again,*r he*r cannot*r see*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God.”*r
“How*p can anyone be born when he is old?” Nicodemus asked him. “Can he enter his mother’s womb a second time and be born?”
Jesus*p answered, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r unless*r someone*r is*r born*r of*r water*r and*r the*r Spirit,*r he*r cannot*r enter*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God.*r
Whatever*r is*r born*r of*r the*r flesh*r is*r flesh,*r and*r whatever*r is*r born*r of*r the*r Spirit*r is*r spirit.*r
Do*r not*r be*r amazed*r that*r I*r told*r you*r that*r you*r must*r be*r born*r again.*r

The*r wind*r blows*r where*r it*r pleases,*r and*r you*r hear*r its*r sound,*r but*r you*r don’t*r know*r where*r it*r comes*r from*r or*r where*r it*r is*r going.*r So*r it*r is*r with*r everyone*r born*r of*r the*r Spirit.”*r
“How*p can these things be?” asked Nicodemus.
“Are*rp you*r a*r teacher*r of*r Israel*r and*r don’t*r know*r these*r things?”*r Jesus replied.
“Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r we*r speak*r what*r we*r know*r and*r we*r testify*r to*r what*r we*r have*r seen,*r but*r you*r do*r not*r accept*r our*r testimony.*r
If*r I*r have*r told*r you*r about*r earthly*r things*r and*r you*r don’t*r believe,*r how*r will*r you*r believe*r if*r I*r tell*r you*r about*r heavenly*r things?*r
No*r one*r has*r ascended*r into*r heaven*r except*r the*r one*r who*r descended*r from*r heaven*r — the*r Son*r of*r Man.*r
“Just*rp as*r Moses*r lifted*r up*r the*r snake*r in*r the*r wilderness,*r so*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r must*r be*r lifted*r up,*r
so*r that*r everyone*r who*r believes*r in*r him*r may*r have*r eternal*r life.*r

For*r God*r loved*r the*r world*r in*r this*r way:*r He*r gave*r his*r one*r and*r only*r Son,*r so*r that*r everyone*r who*r believes*r in*r him*r will*r not*r perish*r but*r have*r eternal*r life.*r
For*r God*r did*r not*r send*r his*r Son*r into*r the*r world*r to*r condemn*r the*r world,*r but*r to*r save*r the*r world*r through*r him.*r

Anyone*r who*r believes*r in*r him*r is*r not*r condemned,*r but*r anyone*r who*r does*r not*r believe*r is*r already*r condemned,*r because*r he*r has*r not*r believed*r in*r the*r name*r of*r the*r one*r and*r only*r Son*r of*r God.*r
This*r is*r the*r judgment:*r The*r light*r has*r come*r into*r the*r world,*r and*r people*r loved*r darkness*r rather*r than*r the*r light*r because*r their*r deeds*r were*r evil.*r
For*r everyone*r who*r does*r evil*r hates*r the*r light*r and*r avoids*r it,*r so*r that*r his*r deeds*r may*r not*r be*r exposed.*r
But*r anyone*r who*r lives*r by*r the*r truth*r comes*r to*r the*r light,*r so*r that*r his*r works*r may*r be*r shown*r to*r be*r accomplished*r by*r God.”*r
Jesus and John the Baptist
After*p this, Jesus and his disciples went to the Judean countryside, where he spent time with them and baptized.
John*p also was baptizing in Aenon near Salim, because there was plenty of water there. People were coming and being baptized,
since John had not yet been thrown into prison.
Then*p a dispute arose between John’s disciples and a Jew about purification.
So they came to John and told him, “Rabbi, the one you testified about, and who was with you across the Jordan, is baptizing — and everyone is going to him.”
John*p responded, “No one can receive anything unless it has been given to him from heaven.
You yourselves can testify that I said, ‘I am not the Messiah, but I’ve been sent ahead of him.’
He who has the bride is the groom. But the groom’s friend, who stands by and listens for him, rejoices greatly at the groom’s voice. So this joy of mine is complete.
He must increase, but I must decrease.”
The One from Heaven
The*p one who comes from above is above all. The one who is from the earth is earthly and speaks in earthly terms. The one who comes from heaven is above all.
He testifies to what he has seen and heard, and yet no one accepts his testimony.
The one who has accepted his testimony has affirmed that God is true.
For the one whom God sent speaks God’s words, since he gives the Spirit without measure.
The Father loves the Son and has given all things into his hands.
The one who believes in the Son has eternal life, but the one who rejects the Son will not see life; instead, the wrath of God remains on him.
John 4
Jesus and the Samaritan Woman
When*p Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard he was making and baptizing more disciples than John
(though Jesus himself was not baptizing, but his disciples were),
he left Judea and went again to Galilee.
He had to travel through Samaria;
so he came to a town of Samaria called Sychar near the property that Jacob had given his son Joseph.
Jacob’s well was there, and Jesus, worn out from his journey, sat down at the well. It was about noon.
A*p woman of Samaria came to draw water. “Give*rp me*r a*r drink,”*r Jesus said to her,
because his disciples had gone into town to buy food.
“How*p is it that you, a Jew, ask for a drink from me, a Samaritan woman?” she asked him. For Jews do not associate with Samaritans.

Jesus*p answered, “If*r you*r knew*r the*r gift*r of*r God,*r and*r who*r is*r saying*r to*r you,*r ‘Give*r me*r a*r drink,’*r you*r would*r ask*r him,*r and*r he*r would*r give*r you*r living*r water.”*r
“Sir,”*p said the woman, “you don’t even have a bucket, and the well is deep. So where do you get this ‘living water’?
You aren’t greater than our father Jacob, are you? He gave us the well and drank from it himself, as did his sons and livestock.”
Jesus*p said, “Everyone*r who*r drinks*r from*r this*r water*r will*r get*r thirsty*r again.*r

But*r whoever*r drinks*r from*r the*r water*r that*r I*r will*r give*r him*r will*r never*r get*r thirsty*r again.*r In*r fact,*r the*r water*r I*r will*r give*r him*r will*r become*r a*r well*r of*r water*r springing*r up*r in*r him*r for*r eternal*r life.”*r
“Sir,”*p the woman said to him, “give me this water so that I won’t get thirsty and come here to draw water.”
“Go*rp call*r your*r husband,”*r he told her, “and*r come*r back*r here.”*r
“I*p don’t have a husband,” she answered. “You*rp have*r correctly*r said,*r ‘I*r don’t*r have*r a*r husband,’”*r Jesus said.
“For*r you’ve*r had*r five*r husbands,*r and*r the*r man*r you*r now*r have*r is*r not*r your*r husband.*r What*r you*r have*r said*r is*r true.”*r
“Sir,”*p the woman replied, “I see that you are a prophet.
Our ancestors worshiped on this mountain, but you Jews say that the place to worship is in Jerusalem.”
Jesus*p told her, “Believe*r me,*r woman,*r an*r hour*r is*r coming*r when*r you*r will*r worship*r the*r Father*r neither*r on*r this*r mountain*r nor*r in*r Jerusalem.*r
You*r Samaritans*r worship*r what*r you*r do*r not*r know.*r We*r worship*r what*r we*r do*r know,*r because*r salvation*r is*r from*r the*r Jews.*r

But*r an*r hour*r is*r coming,*r and*r is*r now*r here,*r when*r the*r true*r worshipers*r will*r worship*r the*r Father*r in*r Spirit*r and*r in*r truth.*r Yes,*r the*r Father*r wants*r such*r people*r to*r worship*r him.*r
God*r is*r spirit,*r and*r those*r who*r worship*r him*r must*r worship*r in*r Spirit*r and*r in*r truth.”*r
The*p woman said to him, “I know that the Messiah is coming” (who is called Christ). “When he comes, he will explain everything to us.”
Jesus*p told her, “I,*r the*r one*r speaking*r to*r you,*r am*r he.”*r
The Ripened Harvest
Just*p then his disciples arrived, and they were amazed that he was talking with a woman. Yet no one said, “What do you want?” or “Why are you talking with her?”
Then*p the woman left her water jar, went into town, and told the people,
“Come, see a man who told me everything I ever did. Could this be the Messiah?”
They left the town and made their way to him.
In*p the meantime the disciples kept urging him, “Rabbi, eat something.”
But*p he said, “I*r have*r food*r to*r eat*r that*r you*r don’t*r know*r about.”*r
The*p disciples said to one another, “Could someone have brought him something to eat?”
“My*rp food*r is*r to*r do*r the*r will*r of*r him*r who*r sent*r me*r and*r to*r finish*r his*r work,”*r Jesus told them.

“Don’t*r you*r say,*r ‘There*r are*r still*r four*r more*r months,*r and*r then*r comes*r the*r harvest’?*r Listen*r to*r what*r I’m*r telling*r you:*r Open*r your*r eyes*r and*r look*r at*r the*r fields,*r because*r they*r are*r ready*r for*r harvest.*r
The*r reaper*r is*r already*r receiving*r pay*r and*r gathering*r fruit*r for*r eternal*r life,*r so*r that*r the*r sower*r and*r reaper*r can*r rejoice*r together.*r
For*r in*r this*r case*r the*r saying*r is*r true:*r ‘One*r sows*r and*r another*r reaps.’*r
I*r sent*r you*r to*r reap*r what*r you*r didn’t*r labor*r for;*r others*r have*r labored,*r and*r you*r have*r benefited*r from*r their*r labor.”*r
The Savior of the World
Now*p many Samaritans from that town believed in him because of what the woman said when she testified, “He told me everything I ever did.”
So when the Samaritans came to him, they asked him to stay with them, and he stayed there two days.
Many more believed because of what he said.
And they told the woman, “We no longer believe because of what you said, since we have heard for ourselves and know that this really is the Savior of the world.”
A Galilean Welcome
After*p two days he left there for Galilee.
(Jesus himself had testified that a prophet has no honor in his own country.)
When they entered Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him because they had seen everything he did in Jerusalem during the festival. For they also had gone to the festival.
The Second Sign: Healing an Official’s Son
He*p went again to Cana of Galilee, where he had turned the water into wine. There was a certain royal official whose son was ill at Capernaum.
When this man heard that Jesus had come from Judea into Galilee, he went to him and pleaded with him to come down and heal his son, since he was about to die.
Jesus*p told him, “Unless*r you*r people*r see*r signs*r and*r wonders,*r you*r will*r not*r believe.”*r
“Sir,”*p the official said to him, “come down before my boy dies.”
“Go,”*rp Jesus told him, “your*r son*r will*r live.”*r The man believed what Jesus said to him and departed.
While*p he was still going down, his servants met him saying that his boy was alive.
He asked them at what time he got better. “Yesterday at one in the afternoon the fever left him,” they answered.
The father realized this was the very hour at which Jesus had told him, “Your*r son*r will*r live.”*r So he himself believed, along with his whole household.
Now*p this was also the second sign Jesus performed after he came from Judea to Galilee.
John 5
The Third Sign: Healing the Sick
After*p this, a Jewish festival took place, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
By the Sheep Gate in Jerusalem there is a pool, called Bethesda in Aramaic, which has five colonnades.
Within these lay a large number of the disabled — blind, lame, and paralyzed.
One*p man was there who had been disabled for thirty-eight years.
When Jesus saw him lying there and realized he had already been there a long time, he said to him, “Do*r you*r want*r to*r get*r well?”*r
“Sir,”*p the disabled man answered, “I have no one to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up, but while I’m coming, someone goes down ahead of me.”
“Get*rp up,”*r Jesus told him, “pick*r up*r your*r mat*r and*r walk.”*r
Instantly the man got well, picked up his mat, and started to walk. Now*p that day was the Sabbath,
and so the Jews said to the man who had been healed, “This is the Sabbath. The law prohibits you from picking up your mat.”
He*p replied, “The man who made me well told me, ‘Pick*r up*r your*r mat*r and*r walk.’”*r
“Who*p is this man who told you, ‘Pick*r up*r your*r mat*r and*r walk’?”*r they asked.
But the man who was healed did not know who it was, because Jesus had slipped away into the crowd that was there.
After*p this, Jesus found him in the temple and said to him, “See,*r you*r are*r well.*r Do*r not*r sin*r anymore,*r so*r that*r something*r worse*r doesn’t*r happen*r to*r you.”*r
The man went and reported to the Jews that it was Jesus who had made him well.
Therefore, the Jews began persecuting Jesus because he was doing these things on the Sabbath.
Honoring the Father and the Son
Jesus*p responded to them, “My*r Father*r is*r still*r working,*r and*r I*r am*r working*r also.”*r
This is why the Jews began trying all the more to kill him: Not only was he breaking the Sabbath, but he was even calling God his own Father, making himself equal to God.

Jesus*p replied, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r the*r Son*r is*r not*r able*r to*r do*r anything*r on*r his*r own,*r but*r only*r what*r he*r sees*r the*r Father*r doing.*r For*r whatever*r the*r Father*r does,*r the*r Son*r likewise*r does*r these*r things.*r
For*r the*r Father*r loves*r the*r Son*r and*r shows*r him*r everything*r he*r is*r doing,*r and*r he*r will*r show*r him*r greater*r works*r than*r these*r so*r that*r you*r will*r be*r amazed.*r
And*r just*r as*r the*r Father*r raises*r the*r dead*r and*r gives*r them*r life,*r so*r the*r Son*r also*r gives*r life*r to*r whom*r he*r wants.*r
The*r Father,*r in*r fact,*r judges*r no*r one*r but*r has*r given*r all*r judgment*r to*r the*r Son,*r
so*r that*r all*r people*r may*r honor*r the*r Son*r just*r as*r they*r honor*r the*r Father.*r Anyone*r who*r does*r not*r honor*r the*r Son*r does*r not*r honor*r the*r Father*r who*r sent*r him.*r
Life and Judgment

“Truly*rp I*r tell*r you,*r anyone*r who*r hears*r my*r word*r and*r believes*r him*r who*r sent*r me*r has*r eternal*r life*r and*r will*r not*r come*r under*r judgment*r but*r has*r passed*r from*r death*r to*r life.*r
“Truly*rp I*r tell*r you,*r an*r hour*r is*r coming,*r and*r is*r now*r here,*r when*r the*r dead*r will*r hear*r the*r voice*r of*r the*r Son*r of*r God,*r and*r those*r who*r hear*r will*r live.*r
For*r just*r as*r the*r Father*r has*r life*r in*r himself,*r so*r also*r he*r has*r granted*r to*r the*r Son*r to*r have*r life*r in*r himself.*r
And*r he*r has*r granted*r him*r the*r right*r to*r pass*r judgment,*r because*r he*r is*r the*r Son*r of*r Man.*r
Do*r not*r be*r amazed*r at*r this,*r because*r a*r time*r is*r coming*r when*r all*r who*r are*r in*r the*r graves*r will*r hear*r his*r voice*r

and*r come*r out — those*r who*r have*r done*r good*r things,*r to*r the*r resurrection*r of*r life,*r but*r those*r who*r have*r done*r wicked*r things,*r to*r the*r resurrection*r of*r condemnation.*r

“I*rp can*r do*r nothing*r on*r my*r own.*r I*r judge*r only*r as*r I*r hear,*r and*r my*r judgment*r is just, because*r I*r do*r not*r seek*r my*r own*r will,*r but*r the*r will*r of*r him*r who*r sent*r me.*r
Witnesses to Jesus
“If*rp I*r testify*r about*r myself,*r my*r testimony*r is*r not*r true.*r
There*r is*r another*r who*r testifies*r about*r me,*r and*r I*r know*r that*r the*r testimony*r he*r gives*r about*r me*r is*r true.*r
You*r sent*r messengers*r to*r John,*r and*r he*r testified*r to*r the*r truth.*r
I*r don’t*r receive*r human*r testimony,*r but*r I*r say*r these*r things*r so*r that*r you*r may*r be*r saved.*r
